aboutme-ph3: Lately I've worked a little bit on web development with the building of this website and I've also managed to create a raycaster in C. I'm also learning Rust and OpenGL as I'm planning to create a 3D multiplayer game totally from scratch (including the game engine) with two friends starting in February 2023 (school project chosen by us). My experience in GLSL combined with OpenGL will allow me to create and incorporate my own shaders into the game.

I also have a deep interest in drawing and music as well as video games (I mostly play Terraria, I love this game!). Don't hesitate to check the Education section if you're interested!

project-description4-1: Graphical interface built from scratch allowing the user to cast light (rays) on edges and curves.
project-description4-2: The user can draw curves by placing points on the screen. Each fragment of curve drawn correspond to a cubic Bézier curve which is connected to the following curve with a C² junction. Therefore, the global curve (made of all the fragments) drown actually represents a spline. It is possible to draw several splines on the screen by switching to another button of the panel and going back to the 'Curves' button.
project-description4-3: It is also possible to move the curve and change its appearance by sliding the white point (see examples below).
project-description4-4: The number of rays displayed in the screen can be set up to 3000 using only edges, and up to 250 using Bézier curves.
project-description4-5: This project allowed me to apply directly my mathematical knowledge (regarding geometry modeling) to a concrete project. It also enabled me to work again on evenemential programming, optimization and other aspects of programming.
